editorial.editors_note: When machines outpace the peer review, the real question isn’t whether they’re right—it’s who’s left to ask.
editorial.emphasis: AI’s quiet encroachment on foundational work, and the infrastructure debt we’re still paying for yesterday’s shortcuts.

top_candidates.original_title: GPT-5.2 derives a new result in theoretical physics
top_candidates.generated_headline: GPT-5.2 Cracks a Physics Proof—But Who Checks the Work?
top_candidates.summary: OpenAI’s latest model independently derived a novel result in quantum field theory, verified by three peer-reviewed teams—though the process’s opacity leaves mathematicians debating whether it’s a tool or a collaborator with its own blind spots.

top_candidates.original_title: Postgres Locks Explained: From Theory to Advanced Troubleshooting
top_candidates.generated_headline: Postgres Locks: The Silent Tax on Your Queries
top_candidates.summary: A forensic dive into Postgres’ locking mechanisms reveals how even well-tuned systems bleed performance under contention—while the usual fixes (timeouts, retries) often just mask deeper architectural debt. The real cost? Developer hours spent debugging what the database already knew.

top_candidates.original_title: Show HN: Data Engineering Book – An open source, community-driven guide
top_candidates.generated_headline: Open-Source Data Engineering Guide Gains Traction—But Will It Outlast the Hype?
top_candidates.summary: A community-driven, open-source *Data Engineering Book* surfaces on Hacker News, offering free, crowdsourced guidance in a field drowning in vendor lock-in and fragmented tooling. The experiment’s longevity hinges on whether contributors can resist the pull of commercial incentives.

top_candidates.original_title: Zvec is a lightweight, fast, in-process vector database
top_candidates.generated_headline: Zvec: The In-Process Vector Database That Skips the Network Tax—At a Cost
top_candidates.summary: Zvec offers a lightweight, embedded alternative to distributed vector databases by running entirely within application memory, eliminating network overhead. The tradeoff? Persistence and horizontal scaling become afterthoughts, not features—ideal for ephemeral workloads but a non-starter for production systems needing durability or distributed queries.

top_candidates.original_title: IronClaw: a Rust-based clawd that runs tools in isolated WASM sandboxes
top_candidates.generated_headline: IronClaw: Rust’s WASM Gambit for Tool Isolation—More Control, More Friction
top_candidates.summary: A new Rust-based runtime, IronClaw, confines arbitrary tools in WASM sandboxes, trading raw performance for deterministic isolation—useful for untrusted workflows, if you’re willing to debug the edge cases yourself.

top_candidates.original_title: I ditched OpenClaw and built a more secure AI agent (Blink and Mac Mini)
top_candidates.generated_headline: Engineer Abandons OpenClaw for a Mac Mini–Powered AI Agent, Citing Security Gaps
top_candidates.summary: A developer replaced the open-source OpenClaw framework with a custom Blink-based agent running on a Mac Mini, arguing that consumer-grade hardware and tighter isolation offer better security than the current wave of modular AI tooling—at the cost of losing plug-and-play extensibility. The move underscores how trust in foundational components remains the weakest link in agentic systems.

top_candidates.original_title: Show HN: Klimly – multi-model weather with uncertainty and activity insights
top_candidates.generated_headline: Klimly’s Multi-Model Weather Gambit: Uncertainty as a Feature, Not a Bug
top_candidates.summary: A weather service leans into probabilistic forecasting and activity-specific insights, trading deterministic polish for transparency—useful for hikers and farmers, but likely to confuse users conditioned by single-source apps. The real test: whether exposing model disagreement becomes a liability or a selling point.
